{{short description|Edible species of coral fungus n the family Gomphaceae found in North America, North Africa, Europe, Australia, and Asia}}

'''''Ramaria botrytis''''', commonly known as the '''clustered coral''', the '''pink-tipped coral mushroom''', or the '''cauliflower coral''', is an [[edible mushroom|edible]] species of [[coral fungus]] in the family [[Gomphaceae]]. Its robust [[basidiocarp|fruit body]] can grow up to {{convert|15|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} in diameter and {{convert|20|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} tall, and resembles some [[coral|marine coral]]. Its dense branches, which originate from a stout, massive base, are swollen at the tips and divided into several small branchlets. The branches are initially whitish but age to [[buff (color)|buff]] or [[tan (color)|tan]], with tips that are pink to reddish. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is thick and white. The [[spore]]s, yellowish in [[spore print|deposit]], are [[ellipsoid]], feature longitudinal striations, and measure about 13.8 by 4.7 [[micrometre|micrometers]].

The [[type species]] of the genus ''[[Ramaria]]'', ''R. botrytis'' was first [[species description|described]] scientifically in 1797 by mycologist [[Christiaan Hendrik Persoon]]. A widely distributed species, it is found in North America, North Africa, central and eastern Europe, Australia, and Asia. The fungus is [[mycorrhiza]]l with [[broadleaf trees]], and fruits on the ground in wooded areas. There are several species of coral fungi that are superficially similar in appearance to ''R. botrytis'', and although comparison of habitat or characteristics like color or branching [[morphology (biology)|morphology]] is often sufficient for identification, sometimes [[microscopy]] is required to definitively distinguish between them. Fruit bodies of ''Ramaria botrytis'' are edible, and young specimens have a mild, fruity taste. Some authors warn of [[laxative]] effects in susceptible individuals. The fungus contains several [[chemical compounds]] with ''[[in vitro]]'' [[biological activity]], and fruit bodies have [[antimicrobial]] activity against several species and strains of [[drug-resistant]] bacteria that [[pathogen|cause disease]] in humans.

==Taxonomy and classification==
The species was first named as ''Clavaria botrytis'' in 1797 by [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]].<ref name="Persoon 1797"/> In 1821, [[Elias Magnus Fries]] [[sanctioned name|sanctioned]] the genus name ''[[Clavaria]]'', and treated ''[[Ramaria]]'' as a [[section (biology)|section]] of ''Clavaria''.<ref name="Fries 1821"/> It was given its current name in 1918 by [[Adalbert Ricken]].<ref name="Ricken 1918"/> Obsolete historical [[Synonym (biology)|synonyms]] include [[Gotthold Hahn]]'s 1883 ''Corallium botrytis''<ref name="Hahn 1883"/> and [[A. A. Pearson]]'s [[variety (botany)|variety]] ''Clavaria botrytis'' var. ''alba'',<ref name="Pearson 1946"/> which is no longer recognized as an independent [[taxon]].<ref name="urlFungorum: Ramaria botrytis"/> Currie Marr and [[Daniel Elliot Stuntz|Daniel Stuntz]] described the variety ''R. botrytis'' var. ''aurantiiramosa'' in their 1973 [[monograph]] of western [[Washington (state)|Washington]] ''Ramaria'';<ref name="Marr1973 pp.38-9">Marr and Stuntz (1973), pp. 38–9.</ref> Edwin Schild and G. Ricci described variety ''compactospora'' from Italy in 1998.<ref name="Schild 1998"/> In 1950, [[E.J.H. Corner]] published [[George F. Atkinson]]'s 1908 ''Clavaria holorubella'' as ''R. botrytis'' var. ''holorubella'',<ref name="Corner 1950"/> but this taxon is now known as the independent species ''Ramaria holorubella''.<ref name="urlFungorum: Ramaria holorubella"/>

The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] ''botrytis'' is derived from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] word {{lang|grc|βότρυς}} (''botrus'') meaning "bunch of grapes".<ref name="Rea 1922"/> The species is [[common name|commonly known]] as the "cauliflower coral",<ref name="McKnight 1987"/> the "pink-tipped coral mushroom",<ref name="Arora p.656">Arora (1986), [https://books.google.com/books?id=86tM01VsFG0C&pg=RA1-PA656 p. 656.]</ref> or the "rosso coral".<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> In the [[Cofre de Perote]] region of [[Veracruz]], Mexico, ''R. botrytis'' is known by the local names ''escobea'', meaning "little broom", or ''pechuga'', meaning "breast meat of chicken".<ref name="Jarvis 2004"/>

''Ramaria botrytis'' was designated the [[type species]] of ''Ramaria'' in 1933 by [[Marinus Anton Donk]].<ref name="Petersen 1968"/> Modern [[molecular phylogenetics|molecular]] analysis indicates that ''Ramaria'' is a [[polyphyletic]] assemblage of species with [[clavarioid fungi|clavarioid]] fruit bodies.<ref name="Humpert 2001"/><ref name="Hosaka 2006"/> According to the infrageneric [[classification (biology)|classification]] scheme proposed by Marr and Stuntz, ''R. botrytis'' is included in the [[subgenus]] ''Ramaria'', which includes species that have grooved spores, [[clamp connections|clamps]] present in the [[hypha]]e, and fruit bodies with a large, profusely branched cauliflower-like appearance.<ref name="Marr1973 pp.38-9"/> [[Phylogenetic]] analysis of nuclear [[28S ribosomal RNA|large subunit]] [[ribosomal DNA]] suggests that ''R. botrytis'' is closely related to ''[[Ramaria rubripermanens|R. rubripermanens]]'' and ''[[Ramaria rubrievanescens|R. rubrievanescens]]'', and that these species form a [[cladistics|clade]] that is [[sister group|sister]] (sharing a recent [[common descent|common ancestor]]) to the [[false truffle]] genus ''[[Gautieria]]'', the most [[Synapomorphy|derived]] group within the studied [[taxon|taxa]].<ref name="Humpert 2001"/>

==Description==
[[File:Ramaria botrytis 299869.jpg|thumb|left|The branches are whitish to buff with reddish tips.]]
The [[basidiocarp|fruit bodies]] produced by the fungus are {{convert|7|to|15|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} wide and {{convert|6|to|20|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} tall.<ref name="Corner 1950"/> They are fleshy cauliflower-like masses with a stout central stem that splits into a few lower primary branches before branching densely above. The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is short and thick—between {{convert|1.5|and|6|cm|in|1|abbr=on}} in diameter—and tapers downward. Initially white, in age both the stem and branches turn pale yellow to [[buff (color)|buff]] to [[tan (color)|tan]].<ref name="Arora p.656"/> Old fruit bodies can fade to become almost white,<ref name="Coker 1923"/> or may be [[ochre]] due to fallen spores.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> The branching pattern is irregular, with the primary branches few and thick—typically {{convert|2|–|3|cm|in|1|abbr=on}}—and the final branches slender (2–3 mm),<ref name="Arora p.656"/> and usually terminated with five to seven branchlets.<ref name="Marr1973 pp.38-9"/> The branchlet tips are pink to purplish-red. The [[trama (mycology)|flesh]] is solid and white,<ref name="Arora p.656"/> and has an odor described variously as indistinct<ref name="Jordan 2004"/> or pleasant.<ref name="Kibby 1994"/> A drop of [[Melzer's reagent]] applied to the stem tissue reveals a weak [[amyloid (mycology)|amyloid]] staining [[Chemical tests in mushroom identification|reaction]] that often requires more than 30 minutes to develop. This reaction can be used to help distinguish ''R. botrytis'' from other similar fungi.<ref name="Marr1973 pp.38-9"/>
[[File:Ramaria botrytis 190863.jpg|thumb|180px|right|The cylindrical to S-shaped spores bear characteristic longitudinal striations.]]
[[Basidiospore|Spore]]s are produced by [[basidia]] on the outer surface of the branches. Viewed in [[spore print|deposit]], the spores are pale yellow. Microscopically, they have fine longitudinal or oblique striations that often fuse together in a vein-like network. They range in shape from roughly cylindrical to sigmoid (curved like the letter "S"), and their dimensions are 12–16 by 4–5 [[micrometre|µm]].<ref name="Burt 1922"/><ref name="Ellis 1990"/> Basidia are four-spored (occasionally two-spored), and measure 59–82 by 8–11 µm. The [[sterigma]]ta (slender projections of the basidia that attach to the spores) are 4–8 µm long. The [[hymenium]] and subhymenium (the tissue layer immediately under the hymenium) combined are about 80 µm thick. Hyphae comprising the subhymenium are interwoven, 2.5–4.5 µm in diameter, thin-walled, and clamped.<ref name="Marr1973 pp.38-9"/>

The variety ''R. botrytis'' var. ''aurantiiramosa'' is distinguished from the more common variety by the orange color of the upper branches.<ref name="Castellano 1999"/> Variety ''compactospora'' tends to show a more pronounced wine-red, purple, or reddish color in the branch tips, and has smaller spores measuring 9.2–12.8 by 4–5.4 µm.<ref name="Schild 1998"/>

===Similar species===

Distinctive features of ''Ramaria botrytis'' include its large size, the orange, reddish, or purplish branchlets, striate spores with dimensions averaging 13.8 by 4.7 µm, and a weak amyloid staining reaction of the stem tissue.<ref name="Marr1973 pp.38-9"/> ''[[Ramaria rubripermanens|R. rubripermanens]]'' has reddish terminal branches, a stout form, and striate spores, but may be distinguished from ''R. botrytis'' by its much shorter spores.<ref name="Marr1973 pp.38-9"/> Other species with which ''R. botrytis'' may be confused include: ''[[Ramaria formosa|R. formosa]]'', which has branches that are pinker than ''R. botrytis'', and yellow-tipped; ''[[Ramaria caulifloriformis|R. caulifloriformis]]'', found in the [[Great Lakes]] region of the United States, whose branch tips darken with age; ''[[Ramaria strasseri|R. strasseri]]'', which has yellow to brown branch tips; ''[[Ramaria rubrievanescens|R. rubrievanescens]]'', which has branches in which the pink color fades after picking or in mature fruit bodies; and ''[[Ramaria botrytoides|R. botrytoides]]'', which is most reliably distinguished from ''R. botrytis'' by its smooth spores.<ref name="McKnight 1987"/> The European species ''[[Ramaria rielii|R. rielii]]'', often confused with ''R. botrytis'' and sometimes considered synonymous, can be distinguished by microscopic characteristics: ''R. reilii'' lacks the clamped hyphae of ''R. botrytis'', its spores are longer and wider, and they have warts instead of striations.<ref name="Daniëls 2000"/> The North American species ''[[Ramaria araiospora|R. araiospora]]'', though superficially similar to ''R. botrytis'', has several distinguishing characteristics: it grows under [[Tsuga|hemlock]]; it has reddish to [[magenta]] branches with orange to yellowish tips; it lacks any discernible odor; it has warted, somewhat cylindrical spores averaging 9.9 by 3.7 µm; and it has non-amyloid stem tissue.<ref>Marr and Stuntz (1973), pp. 55–6.</ref> Uniformly colored bright pink to reddish, ''[[Ramaria subbotrytis|R. subbotrytis]]'' has spores measuring 7–9 by 3–3.5 µm.<ref name="Miller 2006"/>

==Habitat and distribution==
An [[mycorrhiza|ectomycorrhizal]] species, ''Ramaria botrytis'' forms [[mutualism (biology)|mutualistic]] associations with [[broadleaf tree]]s, particularly [[beech]]. In a study to determine the effectiveness of several edible ectomycorrhizal fungi in promoting growth and nutrient accumulation of [[large-fruited red mahogany]] (''Eucalyptus pellita''), ''R. botrytis'' was the best at improving root colonization and [[macronutrient]] uptake.<ref name="Aggangan 2013"/> Records of associations with [[conifer]]s probably represent similar species.<ref name="Roberts 2011"/> Fruit bodies grow on the ground singly, scattered, or in small groups among leaves in woods.<ref name="Burt 1922"/> They can also grow in [[fairy ring]]s.<ref name="Dickinson 1982"/> ''Ramaria botrytis'' is a "[[snowbank fungus]]", meaning it commonly fruits near the edges of melting snowbanks in the spring.<ref>Arora (1986), pp. 46–7.</ref> In Korea, it is prevalent at sites that also produce the choice edible species ''[[Tricholoma matsutake]]''.<ref name="Na 1992"/>

''Ramaria botrytis'' is found in Africa ([[Tunisia]]),<ref name="Saldi 2009"/> Australia,<ref name="May 2003"/> Asia (including the eastern [[Himalayas]] of India,<ref name="Thind 1985"/> Nepal,<ref name="Boa 2004"/> Japan,<ref name="Yaoita 2007"/> Korea,<ref name="Na 1992"/> Pakistan,<ref name="Gardezi 2002"/> China,<ref name="Boa 2004"/> the [[Russian Far East|Far East of Russia]],<ref name="Govorova 2003"/> and Turkey<ref name="Sesli 2006"/>) and Europe (including the Netherlands,<ref name="Tolsma 1999"/> France,<ref name="INPN 2013"/> Portugal,<ref name="Barros 2009"/> Italy,<ref name="Pieroni 1999"/> Bulgaria,<ref name="Boa 2004"/> and Spain<ref name="Rivera 2007"/>). It is also present in Mexico and in Guatemala.<ref name="Boa 2004"/> Widely distributed in North America,<ref name="McKnight 1987"/> it is most common in the southeast and along the [[Pacific Coast]].<ref name="Dickinson 1982"/> The variety ''R. botrytis'' var. ''aurantiiramosa'', limited in distribution to [[Lewis County, Washington]], associates with [[Douglas fir]] (''Pseudotsuga menziesii'') and [[western hemlock]] (''Tsuga heterophylla'').<ref name="Castellano 1999"/> Variety ''compactospora'' is known from [[Sardinia]], Italy, where it has been found growing in sandy soil in forests comprising [[Arbutus unedo|strawberry tree]] (''Arbutus unedo''), [[tree heath]] (''Erica arborea''), and [[holm oak]] (''Quercus ilex'').<ref name="Schild 1998"/>

==Uses==
''Ramaria botrytis'' is an [[edible mushroom|edible]] species, and some rate it as choice.<ref name="Arora p.656"/><ref name="Bessette 1997"/> Its taste is "slight", or "fruity",<ref name="Jordan 2004"/> and has been likened to [[sauerkraut]], green peanuts (fresh harvested peanuts that have not been dehydrated), or pea pods.<ref name="Coker 1923"/> Older fruit bodies develop an acidic flavor.<ref name="Dickinson 1982"/> It is sold in food markets in Japan as ''Nedzumi-take'',<ref name="Yaoita 2007"/> and harvested from the wild in Korea and Nepal.<ref name="Dugan 2011"/> The thick base and main branches require longer cooking than the smaller branchlets.<ref name="Dickinson 1982"/> In the [[Garfagnana]] region of central Italy, the mushroom is stewed, or [[pickling|pickled]] in oil.<ref name="Pieroni 1999"/><ref name="Wright 2001"/> Fruit bodies can be preserved by slicing thinly and drying.<ref name="Burrows 2005"/> One field guide rates the edibility as "questionable", warning of the possible danger of confusing specimens with the poisonous ''Ramaria formosa''.<ref name="McKnight 1987"/> Other authors warn that some individuals may experience [[laxative]] effects from consuming the mushroom.<ref name="Arora p.656"/><ref name="Fergus 2003"/> Caution is advised when collecting fruit bodies near polluted areas, as the species is known to [[bioaccumulate]] toxic [[arsenic]].<ref name="Slekovec 1996"/>

Chemical analysis shows ''R. botrytis'' to have a [[food energy]] value of 154 [[kilojoule]]s per 100 grams of fresh fruit bodies,<ref name="Barros 2008"/> which is comparable to the 120–150 kJ range reported for commercially grown edible mushrooms. As a percentage of [[dry matter]], the fruit bodies contain 39.0% crude [[protein (nutrient)|protein]], 1.4% [[lipid]]s, 50.8% [[carbohydrate]]s, and 8.8% [[Ash (analytical chemistry)|ash]]. The majority of the lipid content comprises [[oleic acid|oleic]] (43.9%), [[linoleic acid|linoleic]] (38.3%), and [[palmitic acid|palmitic]] (9.9%) [[fatty acid]]s.<ref name="Kalač 2009"/>

===Chemistry===
[[File:Nicotianamine.PNG|thumb|right|Nicotianamine]]
[[Extract]]s of the fruit body of ''Ramaria botrytis'' have been shown to favorably influence the growth and development of [[HeLa]] cells grown in [[tissue culture]].<ref name="Chung 1979"/> The mushroom contains [[nicotianamine]], an [[ACE inhibitor]] ([[angiotensin-converting enzyme]]).<ref name="Izawa 2006"/> Nicotianamine is a [[chelation|metal-chelating]] compound essential in iron metabolism and utilization in plants.<ref name="Briat 2007"/> Several [[sterol]]s have been isolated from the fruit bodies, 5α,6α-epoxy-3β-hydroxy-(22''E'')-ergosta-8(14),22-dien-7-one, [[ergosterol peroxide]], [[cerevisterol]], and 9α-hydroxycerevisterol, in addition to the previously unknown [[ceramide]] (2''S'',2{{'}}''R'',3''R'',4''E'',8''E'')-''N''-2'-hydroxyoctadecanoyl-2-amino-9-methyl-4,8-heptade-cadiene-1,3-diol.<ref name="Yaoita 2007"/>

[[Kirby-Bauer antibiotic testing|Laboratory tests]] show that fruit bodies have [[antimicrobial]] activity against several strains of [[drug resistance|drug-resistant]] bacteria that are [[pathogen]]ic in humans. Extracts [[bacteriostatic agent|inhibit]] the growth of the [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] bacteria ''[[Enterococcus faecalis]]'' and ''[[Listeria monocytogenes]]'', and [[bactericide|kill]] the [[Gram-positive bacteria|Gram-positive]] species ''[[Pasteurella multocida]]'', ''[[Streptococcus agalactiae]]'' and ''[[Streptococcus pyogenes|S. pyogenes]]''.<ref name="Alves 2012"/> A separate study demonstrated growth inhibition against ''[[Proteus vulgaris]]''.<ref name="Giri 2012"/>

In a 2009 study of 16 Portuguese edible wild mushroom species, ''R. botrytis'' was shown to have the highest concentration of [[phenolic acid]]s (356.7 [[milligram|mg]] per [[kilogram|kg]] of fresh fruit body), made up largely of [[protocatechuic acid]]; it also had the highest [[antioxidant]] capacity. Phenolic compounds—common in fruits and vegetables—are being scientifically investigated for their potential health benefits associated with reduced risk of [[chronic disease|chronic]] and [[degenerative diseases]].<ref name="Barros 2009"/>
